ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

ALIEN MUSICIANS AND BANDS


    Policy on entry and on protection of local musicians

    1. Mr Lee Kuan Yew asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare what is the present practice of the Government with regard to the entry of alien musicians and musical bands seeking employment in Singapore; and what is the Government's policy on the question of protecting local musicians from unemployment as a result of imported alien musicians.

    Dr Lim Yew Hock: Sir, the entry of alien musicians and musical bands seeking employment in Singapore is governed by the provisions of the Immigration (Prohibition of Entry) Order, 1953. Among the categories of persons set out in the Schedule to that Order who may be admitted into Singapore are persons with professional or specialist qualifications which would enable them to follow their profession or occupation in the Colony without prejudicing the interests of persons already resident in Singapore and possessing corresponding or similar qualifications.

    The present policy of the Government, Sir, designed to protect local musicians from unemployment as a result of imported alien musicians, allows for the admission of not more than two foreign musical bands into Singapore at any one time, subject to the local sponsor who is desirous of importing the foreign band engaging an equal number of local musicians to play with imported bands. The maximum stay in Singapore for each imported band is six months. This policy is at present under review in the light of the experience gained and of the Government's policy on the tourist trade.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Will the Hon. the Minister inform us whether the review is intended to widen or to narrow the limits of entry of alien musicians?

    Dr Lim Yew Hock: It is intended that the number fixed at present of two bands may be increased. One must not overlook the fact that a foreign band here means employment for local musicians.

WIVES AND AGED PARENTS IN CHINA


    Government policy on entry into Singapore

    2. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare if he will state the Government's policy regarding

    (a) the entry from China of wives of Singapore residents who already have wives in Singapore; and

    (b) the entry from China of aged parents of Singapore residents having no other relatives in China to look after them.

    Dr Lim Yew Hock: Sir, with regard to the first part of the question, it is the policy of the Government not to permit entry into Singapore of such wives, invariably referred to as secondary wives. In very special circumstances where the wife in China is the primary wife, the policy may be relaxed. In such cases, certain factors meriting consideration and normally taken into account by the immigration authorities must be satisfactorily proved or established. It will be appreciated that the circumstances of every case vary and, in consequence, each case is thoroughly investigated and carefully considered on its merits.

    The entry of persons described in the second part of the question is governed by paragraph 7 (f) of the Immigration (Prohibition of Entry) Order, 1953.

SECRET BALLOT OF SINGAPORE HARBOUR BOARD WORKERS


    Implementation of recommendation by

    Court of Inquiry into Trade Dispute

    3. Mr Lee Kuan Yew asked the Minister for Labour and Welfare whether and when his Ministry will implement the recommendation for a secret

Column: 2647

ballot in paragraph 9 (iii) (b)* at page 8 of the Report of the Court of Inquiry into the Trade Dispute at the Singapore Harbour Board as contained in Sessional Paper No. S. 7 of 1957.


    *Following is paragraph 9 (iii) (b) -

    "In the case of the Singapore Harbour Staff Association the question of whether or not it is representative of a majority of workers in the Singapore Harbour Board, is more difficult and clouded by the effect of disorderly administrative practices in the keeping of books, accounts and other papers, and with inadequate routine of notification of changes, particularly on the alteration of the Association's rules to include all employees of the Singapore Harbour Board.

    From the evidence presented to us there are signs that something like 4,000 workers were members of one particular union, the Singapore Harbour Board Workers Union, and that with the addition of members of the Singapore Harbour Board Staff Association, the total figure would have been somewhere around 7,000. Whether or not the 4,000 members of the Singapore Harbour Board Workers Union can now be considered as members of the Singapore Harbour Board Workers Union, from the evidence provided by the Registrar of Trade Unions and his Assistant, and from the submission of counsel. It is our opinion,therefore, that further evidence should be collected in the form of a secret ballot by members whose names appear on the membership cards of the Singapore Harbour Board Workers Union and the Singapore Harbour Board Staff Association. The question to be asked should be whether or not each one of these men supports the Singapore Harbour Board Staff Association. The ballot could be easily arranged by the Ministry of Labour in co-operation with the Registrar of Trade Unions and the Supervisor of Elections."


    Dr Lim Yew Hock: Sir, the question is in regard to a suggestion and not a recommendation of the Court of Inquiry. This question is under examination in the light of its wide implications.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Can the Hon. Minister for Labour and Welfare indicate when we can expect an announcement of the decision arrived at?

    Dr Lim Yew Hock: In this case trade union organisations will have to be consulted for their views, and as soon as these views have been gathered by the Labour Department, a decision will be given.

PRESS STATEMENT ON TOURISM


    Purpose of quoting foreign government

    tourist office expenditures

    4. Mr Lee Kuan Yew asked the Chief Secretary what was the purpose of a Singapore Government Press Statement issued at 1200 hours on 17th September, 1957, reference INFS. SE. 57/ 46, which quotes from "Travel News" the figures in U.S. dollars of foreign Government tourist office expenditures.

Column: 2648



    The Acting Chief Secretary (Mr S. T. Stewart): Sir, the purpose of the release to the Press to which the hon. Member refers was to provide information about the financial assistance given by some other governments to promote tourism in their countries.

    Mr Lee Kuan Yew: Sir, will the Hon. the Chief Secretary tell us whether it is part of the duty of the Information Service of Singapore to disseminate information completely irrelevant to Singapore?

    Mr Stewart: Sir, it is a function of the Department of Information Services to stimulate public interest in the Government's activities including the promotion of tourism, and one means of doing so is the issue of news items about what is being done concerning tourism in other countries.

    Mr Stewart: Yes, Sir.

AUDIT OF SINGAPORE GOVERNMENT
ACCOUNTS


    Future arrangements when Pan-Malayan Department is separated

    5. Mr Lee Kuan Yew asked the Chief Secretary who will audit the Accounts of the Government of Singapore and its agencies when the office of the Director of Audit, Malaya, which appointment hitherto has been for both the Federation of Malaya and Singapore, is separated.

    The Acting Chief Secretary (Mr S. T. Stewart): Sir, no decision has yet been made to split up the pan-Malayan office of the Director of Audit, Malaya. Although under the Constitution of the Federation of Malaya the Director of Audit, Malaya, has become the Auditor-General, Federation of Malaya, he is still, as far as Singapore is concerned, Director of Audit, Malaya, and as such he will continue to audit the accounts of the Government of Singapore. Provision for the audit of the accounts of the Government of Singapore will be made in the new Constitution of Singapore.

    'Free the innocent, try all others'

CONCERN AT DETENTION OF DR CHUANG CHU LIN


    Release suggested in view of guarantees

    8. Mr Lee Kuan Yew asked the Chief Secretary whether he is aware of the public concern at the detention under the Banishment Ordinance of Dr Chuang Chu Lin, a person reputed not to be a Communist; and whether, in view of the guarantees and assurances given by responsible Chinese educational and community leaders regarding Dr Chuang's past and future activities, the Government will consider releasing him.

POST OFFICE SAVINGS BANK INTEREST RATE


    Increase suggested to match higher Bank Rate and encourage savings

    10. Mr William Tan asked the Financial Secretary whether in view of the recent increase in the bank rates and in view of the necessity to encourage more savings he will take steps, if necessary by amending legislation, with the object of raising the rate of interest payable on deposits in the Post Office Savings Bank.

    Mr T. M. Hart: Sir, the matter has been considered but it has been decided that it would not be appropriate to change the rate of interest paid by the Post Office Savings Bank.

    The P.O. Savings Bank does not compete with commercial banks or borrowers appealing to investors in the stock market. It does not raise or lower its rate of interest on deposits in sympathy with movements in the stock exchange. It aims at giving people in the lower income group easy facilities for saving small amounts in circumstances of absolute security, and guarantees a rate of interest which remains steady and certain over the years and which is reasonable having regard to the security and the facilities afforded by the Bank. In this connection it is perhaps interesting to note that despite booms and depressions, disasters and victories, the rate of interest paid by the P.O. Savings Bank in the United Kingdom has remained at 2 per cent since 1864; while the rate of interest paid by the P.O. Savings Bank in the United States of America has remained at 2 per cent since 1910.

    It is open to doubt whether the P.O. Savings Bank could in fact raise the rate of interest at the present time even if it were regarded as politic to do so. As the hon., Member is no doubt aware; the P.O. Savings Bank is intended to be a self-supporting institution. Its deposits are required by law to be invested in trustee stocks, which yield a comparatively low rate of interest. Its income

Column: 2653

is derived solely from interest from these investments. From this income, it must meet its operating costs and pay the rate of interest on deposits, which is prescribed by law. It should also, if circumstances permit, build up a reserve against depreciation of investments. If its income is insufficient to meet running expenses and statutory interest charges, the deficit must, by law, be made good by Government. The financial position of the Bank at the present time has been examined. Indications clearly are that if the rate of interest were to be now raised to 3 per cent - which would still be low compared with the yields obtainable elsewhere under stable and secure investment - the Bank would find difficulty in meeting its running expenses and interest charges, and the deficit would have to be met from the general revenue by Government. Such a situation would not, I am sure, be in accordance with the wishes of the hon. Member.

CITY COUNCIL PROPERTY LOSS REVEALED BY AUDIT


    Commission suggested to investigate and recommend action

    11. Mr Lee Choon Eng asked the Minister for Local Government, Lands and Housing whether he has received the Report of the Audit of the Accounts of the Singapore City Council for the year ended 31st December, 1956, by the Director of Audit, Mr H. M. Watson, and

    (a) if he will make a statement on the aforesaid Report; and (b) if he will consider taking steps with the view to the setting up of a Commission of Inquiry to investigate the circumstances which led to the loss of public funds and property as contained in the Report and the lack of control of the Accounting System of the City Council, and to recommend what action is to be taken against the Heads of Departments concerned.

    Inche Abdul Hamid Bin Haji Jumat: Mr Speaker, Sir, in accordance with section 54 (1) of the Municipal Ordinance, the Director of Audit forwarded to

Column: 2654

me on 5th September a copy of his report on the audit of the accounts of the Singapore City Council for the year ended 31st December, 1956. I have asked the President of the City Council if he would let me have the comments of the City Council on this report, and I am informed that it has been referred to the Council's Finance Committee for consideration, and that it was also tabled with no comment attached at a meeting of the Council held on 30th September, 1957.

    I am further informed that the Finance Committee has appointed a sub-commit-tee to consider and enquire into the whole of the Auditor's report, and that it is expected that the sub-committee will report back to the Finance Committee later this month, and that it is only then that the Finance Committee can fully consider the report in the light of the facts which can be placed before it.

    When I have received and studied the full report of the City Council, I will consider whether any step should be taken for further investigations.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Is the Hon. the Minister aware that in many instances, where a committee of the City Council was concerned, funds were waived without the knowledge of the full Council?

    Inche Abdul Hamid: Mr Speaker, Sir, I may or may not be aware of that fact but I am aware of this fact, that in the first instance the responsibility for the proper upkeep of the accounts of the City Council lies on the shoulders of the City Councillors themselves. The hon. Member for Queenstown happens to be a City Councillor and I am sure he should put the question to himself first before he puts it to this Assembly.

    Mr Lee Choon Eng: Under such circumstances will not the Minister feel that a commission of enquiry is most necessary to look into the funds and the audit of the City Council, rather than to leave it in the hands of the City Councillors themselves?

    Mr Speaker: We cannot have a debate.

CANCER


    Treatment facilities in Government Hospitals

    15. Mr Seah Peng Chuan asked the Minister for Health to give details of the existing facilities in Government Hospitals for the treatment of cancer.

    Mr A. J. Braga: Mr Speaker, Sir, the facilities which exist in the Government hospitals for the treatment of persons suffering from cancer are surgical, radium, deep and superficial X-ray therapy. There are today 670 beds available for general and orthopaedic surgery, and a further 40 beds for gynaecology, and amongst these, beds are made available for those seeking treatment for cancer. POST OFFICE SAVINGS DEPOSITS


    Withdrawals over $100 without reference to Kuala Lumpur Headquarters

    16. Mr William Tan asked the Minister for Communications and Works, with reference to the Post Office Savings Bank, whether he will consider making arrangements so as to allow a Singapore depositor to withdraw the whole or any part exceeding $100 of the amount standing to his credit without reference to the Savings Bank Headquarters at Kuala Lumpur.

    Mr Francis Thomas: Consideration has already been given to the matter. Arrangements would not be justified which would enable a depositor to withdraw the whole or any part exceeding $100 of the amount standing to his credit

Column: 2658

without reference being made to accounts kept in the headquarters of the Savings Bank. The purpose of this reference is to ensure the security of the deposits, which security is possibly the chief attraction in the Post Office Savings Bank account. Further, the prevention of fraudulent practices in connection with P.O. Savings Bank accounts can only be effected through some centralised control. The fact that reference has to be made to Kula Lumpur is simply because the P.O. Savings Bank accounts are kept centrally in Kuala Lumpur. If at some future time arrangements are made to keep the accounts in Singapore, it will of course be no longer necessary to refer to Kuala Lumpur.

    Mr William Tan: Cannot a separate headquarters be established in Singapore to deal with these withdrawals?

    Mr Francis Thomas: I think that is really a separate question, Mr Speaker; it involves the whole question of pan-Malayan departments and some rather wide matters of policy.

INDUSTRIAL PROMOTION BOARD


    Progress, and number of applications

    received, approved and rejected

    17. Mr Lim Choon Mong asked the Minister for Commerce and Industry to make a statement regarding the progress made by the Industrial Promotion Board, and also to state

    (i) how many applications for aid have been received;

    (ii)the number of applications that have actually received financial aid;

    (iii)the number of applications still under consideration; and

    (iv) the number of applications for aid that have been rejected.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: The Board has held 13 meetings, Sir, since its inaugural meeting on 1st March, 1957, and the fourteenth meeting will be held on the 30th of this month. The Manager was appointed on 11th April and the Board is at present housed in my Ministry. The Board has so far sanctioned loans

Column: 2659

of $70,000 at 7 per cent interest on long-term credits. Its powers are clearly defined by the Ordinance.

    In answer to sub-question (i), Sir, 45 applications for funds have been received by the Board and each applicant has been interviewed by the Manager. So far only 24 of these applicants have completed the questionnaire sent to them by the Board.

    The Board has also been asked for advice by five concerns and technical assistance is now being given to all five applicants.

    In answer to sub-question (ii), two applicants have received financial aid and also assistance with their technical, legal and managerial problems.

    In answer to sub-question (iii), eight applications are now under investigation. There are also 21 outstanding applications where the applicants have not yet returned the questionnaire to which I referred. The premises of six of these have been visited by the Manager of the Board.

    In answer to sub-question (iv), 14 applications have been rejected but it is likely that at least three of these will be reconsidered if the applicants adopt suggestions made to them by the Board.

    Mr Lim Choon Mong: The Hon. Minister previously assured the Beehoon Association people of help. I would like the Minister to inform the House whether such application has been considered favourably.

    Mr J. M. Jumabhoy: Sir, the assurance I gave to the House was that I would do my best to see whether the Board would consider favourably the application of the Beehoon Co-operative Society. However, it would be very impolitic for me to put pressure on the Board because it is a statutory board, and I think it is not to the interests of Singapore that a Minister should exert pressure on such a Board. If the Board feels that it is not in its interests to grant a loan to any applicant, then it is at liberty to refuse.

Column: 2660



    However, regarding this Beehoon cooperative's application, it has been under consideration and the Manager has met the members of the co-operative and given them some advice on how to reorganise their factories. The problems are very complex. For instance, if they are to install mechanical driers they will have to acquire land and abandon squatter production methods.
